data.text: Schrader Valves or Presta Valves? Adapter on Presta Valves for Cycle Touring

Schrader valves or Presta Valves for cycle touring in Europe? My bike has Presta Valves, while my partnerâ€™s bike has Schrader Valves and, so that as much of our gear as possible is interchangeable, I plan to change the rims on one of the bikes, but Iâ€™m not sure which rims to change. And suggestions or advise?
It's handy to be able to use a garage airline from time to time
data.author: David Renton

data.text: and it's so amazing to do so! Full tires in seconds! My old pump took ten pumps per pound of pressure :/
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Change the rim? Just change the schrader tube to presta tube. And you need an adapter, to use patrol station's pump.
data.author: Broom Wagon

data.text: Pardon my dumb-dumb, but I carry a pump which will accommodate either valve and have an adapter on one of my presta valves so that if I am somewhere that does not accommodate my prestas I am still able to get air. Easy enough to check ALL the boxes for this one and, IMHO, necessary to check all the boxes. (What will you do if - scratch that - WHEN you get a flat?)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Presta and a little brass converter which gives you the ability to use garage air lines and protect the delicate Presta valve closer when using a pump.
data.author: Joe Jones

data.text: I went for Schrader for the concenience and durability. Sure, they can't take as much pressure, but it's fine
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Schwalbe presta tubes come with a stepped 'nut' which holds the smaller valve central in a schrader hole. The little brass adapter is a great accessory
data.author: Paul Eaves

data.text: Forget about changing wheels. Just get one of those little thread on adapters for Shrader to Presta.
data.author: Joe Trudo

data.text: Schrader rims will take a presta valve, you may need an adapter to hold the narrower presta valves in place. Some presta tubes come with a reversible locking nut that has a flange on one side to fit inside the hole in a schader rim. Schrader valves do not fit through a presta rim. I run schrader rims but use both types on inner tubes..... with an adapter for presta.
data.author: Graeme Thomson

data.text: When I was in Belgium and I had a flat and I tried my pump and it was dead. The first 2 places I tried to get a new pump only had ones for Dunlap valves (wtf is a Dunlap valve?) The 3rd place had a pump which converted to all three types....now I'm well prepared
data.author: Perry Walker

data.text: Adapter and a pump that handles both. Easy.
data.author: Jean du Plessis

data.text: Presta
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: Just drill out the presta rims to fit the schrader valve. Done it many times on advice from bike shop.
data.author: Ross Gilbertson

data.text: Yes you could definitaly do that, but the only upside is that you dont need an adapter at a gas station. Keep in mind though, that gas station pumps dont usually go to high pressures. This doesnt matter if you have big tires and dont need to go over maybe 3 bar. I would definitely recommend you to carry a pump anyway so whats the point? Most pumps can take both valves. And any bike shop I can think of has both inner tubes also. But I would also recommend to bring a spare tube, so even if you cant buy one at one specific shop you can still buy one later.. then most of the punctures you can also fix so I really wouldnâ€™t care about the valve. In any case if you still happen to be in a situation when a bike shop doesnâ€™t have a presta tube, you can still drill the rim then and there.
data.author: Viktor Spett

data.text: Viktor Spett All the garage air lines I've ever used go up to 6 Bar.
data.author: Joe Jones

data.text: might be the same for gas stations, I am not sure of the exact value, I just remember it was definitely not enough for my road bike ðŸ˜‚ (8bar+)
data.author: Viktor Spett

data.text: So many opinions! Its almost like it doesnâ€™t even matter!
data.author: Tom Heutte

data.text: Just buy a tiny converter so it won't matter what valves you have. Most pumps have inter changeable heads for both
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: Schrader so you can pump at gas stations.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: Just change the tubes so you both have the same. I'd have thought that one was obvious....Presta normally in Europe.
data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: Ive never seen a rim that only takes presta, but reading the drilling comment, i guess they exist. Just watch fir rim depth too, some tubes have short valves which can make it difficult to get a pump on with deep rims.
data.author: John Dingley

data.text: When I was a kid in the UK we called Presta high pressure valves, and they were pretty much the only valve I saw until bikes started being imported en-masse from Europe. I could be wrong, but I thought Schrader valves were more universally available in Europe, and most of the world. Presta may not be so easy to find. So if you need new valve stems, or tubes, you might find it more difficult. Same if you ever needed a new rim on tour, it might take a bit longer to source one. Unless you are going to be running high pressures, it would seem more convenient, and therefore sensible, to go with Schrader valves, rim, etc. It also means that if you are your partner are both using the same size wheels, you can carry at least one less spare tube, and fewer bits in the repair kit (less stems, one less stem tool, fewer replacement valve caps, and not converter/adaptor for air lines). Just my 2c.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Presta valves were a stupid invention. Schrader has always been a much more user-friendly setup. Definitely more robust! Half the time I use Presta the delicate valve pin at the top ends up getting bent sideways...
data.author: Tom Wojcik

data.text: Presta
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Also confused on this post. Surely just take an adapter for both and / or a pump which fits both. .....
data.author: Nigel Rowe

data.text: Solid tyres - no pump, not repair kit no hassle
data.author: Neil Oliver

data.text: Car puncture repair guys and car pumps in garages are more common than bike repair shops. Schrader for me everyday.
data.author: Dane Hardinge

data.text: I drill out my rims to Schraeder size, because it is the style used on motor vehicles, so I'm able to fill my tubes at petrol stations. I also carry a hand pump with a convertible head in case someone has Presta valves and doesn't have a functional pump.
data.author: Roger Noehren

data.text: Or you could just get an adapter
data.author: Loy Hawkes

data.text: That's what I recommended to customers with Presta tubes and used when I had them many years ago.
data.author: Roger Noehren

data.text: Take any kind, but always have an adaptor, it doesnâ€™t take space or weight, but if you have to by a new tire on the road, you might need it. If you go for a presta, take two adaptors. It is so small that you could lose it Also take a pump with both plugs Have a nice trip ! Please the wind be on your back
data.author: Emile Besse

data.text: Simple question how many cars have presta valves? Right NONE. Go for schrader easier to get inflated anywhere.
data.author: Sol Pearson

data.text: I've never ruined the valve on an otherwise good Schrader tube.
data.author: Gerald Prokop

data.text: Why bother? Most decent pumps cater for both types of valve. So you can carry one less spare inner tube?
data.author: Phil Joyce

data.text: You can run presta tubes in a Schrader rim. All continental presta tubes come with a valve nut designed to do just that. One side of the nut has a flange that fits down into the Schrader hole. So don't spend the money on new rims, just carry a couple of the conversion nuts and all presta tubes....
data.author: Stephen Lodewick
